ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NATIONAL SERVICE DEFERMENT FOR STUDENTS
(Policy)


    1. Encik Wan Hussin bin Hj Zoohri asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) whether there has been any change in the policy of deferment for students studying overseas; and

Column: 1314

(b) how many students have been granted deferment up to the end of 1987 and what were the reasons.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    There has been no change in the policy of deferment for students studying overseas.

Column: 1315



    In 1987, a total of 14,186 students who were due for enlistment for full-time national service, were deferred. Of these, 124 were on overseas studies; 14,062 were on local studies, broken down into 2,448 on Polytechnic courses, 3,966 on 'A' level courses, 2,700 on 'O' level courses, 2,263 on 'N' level courses and 1,695 on VITB courses.

HDB HOUSING ESTATES
(Repairs to damaged grass areas)


    2. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Minister for National Development how much was spent in each of the years 1983 to 1987 to repair and re-turf damaged grass areas in Housing and Development Board estates; what were the main causes of the damage; and what measures his Ministry is taking to reduce such expenses.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the early eighties, the HDB used to spend approximately $300,000 a year to repair and re-turf damaged grass areas in the housing estates. This expenditure was reduced to about $250,000 in 1987.

    Grass areas are damaged mainly because some residents burn joss paper on the grass on festive occasions. The other causes of damage are children playing games and pedestrians taking short cuts. The turfed areas are not designed for such intensive uses and are therefore damaged.

    To seek the cooperation of residents to refrain from indiscriminate burning of joss paper, the HDB has placed metal bins at convenient locations of the blocks, put up posters and distributed pamphlets urging residents to burn joss paper in the containers. HDB is also trying out, on a trial basis, a better designed joss paper burner for use by residents during the festive season.

    The Board mounted periodic campaigns jointly with the Residents' Committees to inculcate in residents a greater sense of social responsibility when burning joss paper. HDB has also appealed for cooperation through the mass media and "Our

Column: 1316

Home" magazine. These campaigns and educational programmes will be intensified.

    To cut down the instances of damage to grass areas by children playing on them, the HDB has worked together with the Residents' Committees to seek the cooperation of the residents to make use of multi-purpose courts, designated play areas and open fields for games.

    To further reduce damage due to short cuts made across turfed areas, the HDB will construct pavements where necessary.

    The HDB, together with the grassroots organizations, is intensifying efforts to reduce damage to grass areas. Ultimately, the success of the measures depends on the cooperation of the residents themselves.

HDB RELOCATION SCHEME IN DELTA CONSTITUENCY


    3. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the present position of the relocation scheme in Delta Constituency; (b) what is the future development plan for the piece of land vacated by the SIT flats under the relocation scheme; and (c) if the Housing and Development Board will assist the hawkers, especially the cooked food stallholders, at the Alexandra Road Market whose businesses have been seriously and increasingly affected because more and more residents are moving out of the 1-room and SIT flats due to either the upgrading process of the residents or the relocation scheme of the HDB.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, within Delta Constituency, the current relocation programme affects 1,721 HDB flats in 21 blocks. 1,108 flats were tenanted when the relocation exercise commenced. As at 1st March 1988, the HDB had relocated 826 tenants. The remaining 282 tenants are being offered flats. Of these, 98 tenants will be rehoused by December this year whereas the balance of 184 tenants will be rehoused next year.

    The vacated land will be redeveloped in two parcels. The HDB has plans to commence construction of 4- and 5-room flats

Column: 1317

in one of the parcels in the early 1990s. The other parcel is being set aside for further complementary development which can include private sector participation.

    The Alexandra Road Market/Hawker Centre is managed by the Ministry of the Environment. I understand that the Ministry is reviewing the long-term policy on markets and cooked food centres, including the future of the Alexandra Road Market.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, will the HDB expedite allocation of flats to the remaining families in those blocks where most of the tenants have moved out?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, in blocks where there is already a very high vacancy rate as a result of tenants moving out, HDB will certainly like to expedite relocation and will try wherever possible to find them alternative accommodation, either in rental flats or in purchase flats.

PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOLS
(Reduction in class size)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

    4. To ask the Minister for Education what progress has been made in reducing the number of students in primary and secondary school classes.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Question 4, Sir.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Mr Chiam is not here, Sir. Question 4.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Backbenchers for coming out so promptly to raise the Question on behalf of the Member for the Opposition.

    Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister. The reduction of class size in primary and secondary schools is a gradual process. It is dependent on two major factors - teachers and school buildings.

Column: 1318



    Class size can be reduced only when there is a corresponding increase in the number of teachers. Efforts have been and are being made to attract more people to join the teaching profession. These efforts are currently being stepped up.

    Smaller class size means more classrooms and school buildings. With secondary schools going single session, the demand for more school buildings will become even greater. It takes time to build schools.

    The reduction of class size is a desirable objective which is being pursued in our quest for excellence in education. However, it cannot be brought about overnight.

COMMUNITY LEADERS SERVING IN CIVIL DEFENCE COORDINATING COMMITTEE
(Recognition for)


    5. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will consider some form of recognition for community leaders serving in the Civil Defence Coordinating Committee, such as long service awards and priority in Housing and Development Board and HUDC housing allocation, awards similar to those given to community leaders serving in other community organizations.

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, since the launching of our Civil Defence Programme in 1982, many Singaporeans have been involved in various Civil Defence activities, including emergency exercises such as water and blood collection, food distribution and shelter exercises. Civil Defence Coordinating Committees (CDCCs) have been formed in every constituency. CDCC leaders play complementary roles as community leaders to those in other grassroots organizations. In fact, many of them are also serving as members of RCs, CCCs or CCMCs. The untiring efforts of the Chairmen and members of the CDCCs have been a major factor in making our Civil Defence Programme a success so far.

Column: 1319



    My Ministry agrees with the Member that the efforts and contributions of these CDCC members must be given due recognition. CDCC members like other grassroots leaders are invited to State functions. They have also been included in the schemes of recognition available to members of other grassroots organizations. These include Long Service Awards under the Ministry of Community Development and the Community Service Awards under the Singapore Civil Defence Force. Last year, 56 CDCC members were individually honoured by the Force for their 5-year contribution to the Civil Defence Programme.

    My Ministry will liaise with other relevant Ministries to see in what other ways CDCC members can be given recognition for their contributions.

SHIPBUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRIES
(Particulars of serious accidents)


    6. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Labour how many serious accidents occurred in the shipbuilding and construction industries during the last five years up to 1987, and what measures his Ministry is taking to further reduce the rate of accidents in these two industries.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of serious accidents, ie, fatal or permanent disablement cases, in the shipbuilding and repairing and construction industries has fallen considerably over the last five years. I have asked the Clerk of Parliament to distribute copies of the detailed accident statistics for the two industries. [Copies of Annex (Cols. 1405 - 1406) distributed to Members.]
Annex - ACCIDENT STATISTICS (1983 - 1987) (Cols. 1405 - 1406)


    In the shipbuilding and repairing industry, the number of fatal accidents dropped from 9 cases in 1983 to 7 cases in 1987 after reaching a peak of 13 cases in 1984. The number of permanent disablement cases also decreased from 16 to 8 cases over the last five years.

    Partly in line with the decline in construction activities, the drop in the number

Column: 1320

of fatal accidents in the construction industry was even sharper, falling from 65 cases in 1983 to 19 cases in 1987. The number of permanent disablement cases fell from 45 cases in 1983 to 16 cases in 1987.

    My Ministry will continue its effort to further reduce accidents in these two industries. In the shipbuilding industry, special attention will be paid to the prevention of fires and explosions and of workers falling from heights. Stringent safety measures to prevent such accidents are already in place. Officers from the Department of Industrial Safety will inspect shipyards regularly to ensure that these measures remain effective. They will also continue to check on shipyards to ensure that qualified safety personnel are appointed and that the safety committees are effective.

    As for the construction industry, the emphasis will still be on the prevention of accidents involving workers falling from heights and workers being struck by falling objects. My Ministry will continue to monitor closely safety at worksites through regular and frequent inspections. Our inspectors will work closely with the safety committees and safety supervisors who are responsible for site safety.

    Further, my Ministry will continue to train and retrain our workers, supervisors and managers so that they are able to practise self-regulation to reduce accidents in the two industries.

FORMER ST JOSEPH'S INSTITUTION AND FORMER TAO NAN SCHOOL BUILDINGS
(Conversion of)


    7. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Community Development what progress has been made to convert (i) the old St Joseph's Institution into an art gallery and (ii) the old Tao Nan School into a museum for children.

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, the conversion of the St Joseph's Institution building into a Fine Arts Museum is one of the

Column: 1321

projects under the Tourism Product Development Plan approved by the Government in principle.

    A preliminary concept plan has already been drawn up by the Public Works Department and they are now making the cost estimates. Next month, we will be sending a study team overseas to visit museums in France and Germany where they have converted old buildings into museums and we will learn from their experiences. If everything goes according to plan, then we will be able to see the museum in four years' time.

    Similarly, with the Tao Nan School. The plan to convert the Tao Nan School building into a Children's Museum is also part of the Tourism Product Development Plan.

    A concept plan has also been completed. And we will be sending a study team to America and Canada to learn from their experience in how to run a Children's Museum and what are in a Children's Museum. According to plan again and if everything goes well, we will see the museum also in four years' time.

CHILD PSYCHIATRIC SERVICE
(Particulars)


    8. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for Health if he will indicate (i) the number and the main problems of children who were seen at the Child Psychiatric Clinic in 1985, 1986, 1987 and (ii) some future plans for further improvements to the child psychiatric service.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, the Child Psychiatric Clinic attended to 1,327 patients in 1985, 1,478 patients in 1986, and 1,605 patients in 1987.

    The three main groups of problems dealt with were, firstly, emotional and behavioural disorders. These accounted for 61% of the cases. Secondly, psychotic illnesses, accounting for 16% of the cases. And, thirdly, mental retardation, including language and learning disorders, which accounted for 14% of the cases.

Column: 1322



    My Ministry plans to extend the child psychiatric services to some of the polyclinics over the next 2-3 years. This will make the service more readily accessible to the community.

     Dr Vasoo: What is the staffing situation in this clinic and would there be plans to integrate the service into the community hospitals which are being planned?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, we have a total of 14 staff that have been allocated to this service. At the present moment they are able to cope quite adequately with the demands. If there is any increase in requirements, we will look into manning the required positions.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, has the Minister done any study to find out whether this increase in the number of attendances at the Child Psychiatric Clinic, especially those with emotional disturbances, has anything to do with the children being separated from their natural mothers and put in the care of baby sitters, foster homes and child care centres?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the Ministry has found no evidence of that. What we believe is that the greater attendances are due to a greater level of awareness from, first, the schools, and secondly, parents, to such behavioural problems which are treatable. The high level of attendances also reflects the greater willingness of parents to bring their children in for treatment and not to be worried by the fact that their children may be stigmatized by the attendances.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Are most of these cases referred to the clinic by the teachers, parents or by GPs?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the schools and our School Health Services account for one-third of the referrals. Our Outpatient Services account for 25% of the referrals, Government hospitals for 10%, and the GPs account for 20% of the referrals.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Will the Minister enlighten this House by indicating how many of these cases are actually due to mental or physical abuse at home?

Column: 1323



     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, I do not have the figures for that. But my reading of the cases is that very few of them are the result of abuse.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, the Minister has not answered my other question. I was trying to find out whether he has plans to integrate the service in the community hospitals.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: We have not made a decision on that yet.

REMISSION OF HOSPITAL FEES
(Figures)


    9. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Acting Minister for Health how many patients have successfully applied for remission of hospital fees because of financial difficulty in all the government hospitals from 1985 up to the latest convenient date.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the total number of patients whose charges were remitted or waived numbered 5,014 from 1985 to December 1987. The total amount remitted and waived amounted to $1.4 million. This represents 0.8% of the total number of hospital bills raised during the period and it shows that the hospital fees are within the means of the vast majority of Singaporeans.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1988 TO 31ST MARCH, 1989



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [7th Allotted Day].

[Mr Deputy Speaker in the Chair]



    Head N (cont.)-

    Resumption of Debate on Question [23rd March, 1988],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head N of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Augustine H.H. Tan.]

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Sir, I will resume where I

Column: 1324

stopped at the Moment of Interruption yesterday, International Foreign Banks.

    Internationally, most foreign banks have over the past two years increased their capital bases. Many with substantial exposures to problem LDC and domestic debts have been able to build up substantial provisions for loan losses. They are therefore in a better position today than they were two years ago. Although a number of foreign banks were affected by domestic Singapore problem loans, adequate provisions have been made through arrangements with their parent banks. Overall, foreign banks in Singapore are profitable. On an aggregate basis, their profits in 1986 were some 17% higher than in 1985. Comparable data for 1987 are not yet available.

Finance companies.

    There are 31 finance companies in Singapore, 15 of which are controlled by banks, 16 independent. The bank-backed companies accounted for 57% of deposits and 52% of total loans in the industry. The financial condition of the industry is sound. The companies have a liquidity ratio of 14.6%, well above the legal requirement of 10%. Their capital adequacy ratio is over 15%, much higher than even for the banks.

    With the recovery in the economy and the property market, the quality of their assets has also improved and the industry's 1987 pretax profits of $113 million was over 200% higher than the figure for 1986.

Stockbroking industry.

    The stockbroking industry was completely restructured in 1986 following the failure of a number of stockbroking companies in the aftermath of the Pan Electric collapse. New legislation was introduced in August 1986 in the form of Securities Industry Act 1986 and the Securities Industry Regulation 1986. The legislation and the regulations prescribe new financial requirements for stockbroking companies to ensure greater prudence in their operations. Besides minimum capital and marginal requirements, limits were also placed on exposure to single clients and to single securities. The breadth and depth of the stockbroking industry was also enhanced

Column: 1325

by allowing financial institutions and corporations to obtain stockbroking licences or take equity in existing firms. Reputable foreign institutions were allowed to hold up to 49% of equity in these companies. There are now 24 member-companies in the SES.

    With these changes and with the recovery in the stock market in 1986/87 the financial condition of the 24 stockbroking companies has greatly improved. In aggregate, their adjusted net capital has increased almost ten-fold, from only $39 million at the end of 1986 to $377 million at the end of last year. Earnings were $170 million in 1987 compared to a loss of $15 million in 1986. The stockbroking industry is now well placed to withstand unforeseen external shocks.

    Despite the severe plunge in local share prices in October last year which was triggered off by a collapse in Wall Street, our stockbroking industry emerged unscathed.

The Futures industry in Singapore.

    Currently, 60 companies are licensed by the MAS under the Futures Trading Act to trade as futures brokers. They operate as members of Simex and the majority are affiliated to major financial institutions such as banks or merchant banks. The industry was profitable in 1987 with a return on capital averaging 14%. The prudential requirements in operations of the industry are carefully monitored by the MAS. Although it has a relatively short history, Simex has proved to be resilient and financially sound. It was severely tested during the October stock market crash and its spill-over effects into the futures market. But it came through with its viability enhanced.

    I will now touch on two specific questions raised by the Member for Whampoa. He says that published data in the Economic Survey of Singapore (1987) shows that the capital to asset ratio of banks in Singapore was 7.4% and whether this was sufficient in today's circumstances. The data in the Economic Survey refers to the total domestic Singapore dollar banking unit or

Column: 1326

system and includes the operations of the 22 foreign banks with full banking licences and another 14 banks with restricted local banking licences which allowed them to accept Singapore dollar deposits from Singapore residents. Because the local branches of foreign banks are the same legal entities as their respective head offices, they are not separately capitalized in Singapore but are required to maintain notional capital in the form of net head office funds. Legally, the entire capital of the parent banks can be called upon to support the local branches' requirements. Without the foreign banks the capital to asset ratios of local banks is over 13%.

    The Member was also concerned that local banks were now more exposed to international banking problems because of the internationalization of the banking system and the widespread practice of inter-bank transactions. It is indeed true that exposure to international risks is now much higher even for banks not directly exposed to bad international debts because of the inter-bank linkages. I should point out, however, that international bank lending is very short term, commonly with maturities ranging from overnight to no more than three months, so that banks have a great deal more flexibility to tailor their inter-bank lendings to their perceptions of risk.

    Finally, I have to say that there can be no iron-clad guarantee of safety in any financial system. In Singapore we have in place a legislation which ensures that banks and other financial institutions operate within conservative prudential requirements. The MAS oversees the provisions of these institutions through a regular programme of inspections and deviations from prudential requirements and practices have to be rectified promptly. With risks heightened as a result of internationalization, financial institutions and their supervisors will simply have to be much more vigilant.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Chairman, Sir, I thank the hon. Minister for his reply which is reassuring. We certainly regained part of our lustre as a financial centre last year when our stock market was able to keep open for trading in spite of the October crash.

Column: 1327



    May I now move on to the second topic, and that is, Manpower Utilisation in the Public Sector. In his Budget Statement, the Minister informed us that the manpower complement of Ministries and those statutory boards funded through the budget will be reduced by 2% and that this is part of the targetted 10% decrease in public sector manpower over a 5-year period announced in 1986.

    There are a number of questions I would like to address to the Minister in this regard. Firstly, what kind of manpower saving does this represent? One could, for example, be saving mostly in terms of daily-rated workers or one could save workers across-the-board, including executive and professional officers. In the case of daily-rated workers, it is very simple to save on such workers by simply contracting work out. But in terms of national manpower requirements, we are not really saving. There may be marginal gain in terms of efficiency if the contracting cost is less than having to maintain these workers at the Ministry level.

    The second question is, we have been automating and mechanizing much of the Civil Service. Are there fruits that are evident from this process by way of manpower saving?

    Thirdly, to what extent are we developing performance indicators or productivity indicators in Government Ministries and statutory boards?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, in my 1986 Budget Statement I announced Government's intention to reduce manpower usage in the public sector. Following the announcement, a programme of inhouse manpower scrutinies was instituted. At the same time, reviews of selected departments were also conducted by the Management Services Department of my Ministry, the Auditor-General's Office and management consultants from the private sector. By the end of 1987, a total of 56 inhouse scrutinies covering selected programmes in seven Ministries had been initiated. For scrutinies which have been completed, savings of 440 posts or about 6% of the total manpower reviewed have been identified. In the case of inhouse scrutinies by the statutory boards, savings

Column: 1328

identified totalled 1,738 posts. As for reviews by external consultants, a total of 2,374 posts have been identified. This amounts to more than 10% of the total manpower reviewed. In all, the reviews by external consultants have covered some 16,700 employees or 14% of the total public sector employment.

    I should like to assure the Member that all reviews have been and will be conducted in an objective and professional manner. The reviews involve comprehensive studies of whether particular tasks need to be carried out at all and, if so, how they can be performed more efficiently. There are no pre-determined targets for staff reductions by divisions or by grade of appointment. In a number of reviews, proportionally more officers in lower grades have been affected than those in higher grades, but this is not surprising as the opportunities for mechanization and computerization are greatest where the work is routine or repetitive.

    In conclusion, I would like to assure the House that manpower reductions will not be at the expense of quality of public service. The manpower reviews completed have not only helped Ministries improve their efficiency but have also enhanced their effectiveness and service to the public as well. Manpower surpluses identified in certain areas have been rechannelled to other higher priority areas and the Budget Division maintains a comprehensive register of indices for various activities which are used for the purpose of checking expenditure requirements by individual ministries and public bodies.

    I have the figures available but because of time constraints, I do not want to read out the specific figures on breakdown of manpower savings by Division of public servants. I will make them available to the Member separately.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, I thank the Minister for his reply.

    May I get on to the third part of my amendment and that has to do with the divestment programme and farming out activities. My purpose in bringing up this subject is to get a progress report on the divestment of Government-linked com-

Column: 1329

panies and the question whether this has been hindered by the stock market crash of last year.

    As to the second part of this subject matter, may I refer to the Auditor-General's Report, 1986-87, paragraphs 136 to 138. In that Report, it was mentioned that the Government ministries managed to farm out $370 million to the private sector. This is something to be welcomed because it means that greater efficiency will result and the private sector's participation in the economy will increase. The Auditor-General, however, also recommended other areas, to which the Finance Ministry apparently agreed, as priority areas for farming out. They are maintenance and repair of vehicles, laboratory and testing services, materials management and office services. May I find out from the Minister what further progress has been made in these areas?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, on privatization, first. The Government commenced its divestment programme in late 1985 and has to-date divested its stake in 22 companies. Of the 22 companies, 13 are fully divested while another nine companies were partially privatized, with the Government's average stake in these companies reduced from over 70% to less than 45%.

Partial privatization or new listings.

    This is to increase the breadth and depth of the local stock market. Priority was given to the flotation of companies into the stock market. SIA was the first candidate to go public with an offer of 100 million shares to the public. In the favourable condition of the stock market in 1986 and up to October 1987, another six companies were also listed. These companies were Singapore National Printers, Resource Development Corporation, Sembawang Maritime, Jurong Shipyard, Singmarine Industries and DBS Land.
